Some letters (of the Egyptian syllabary / proto-alphabet) were so much run down through the ages that they turned from assumed complex sounds into consonants into vowels in their derived alphabets/abjads.

see ğ“¼ Gha q xeno x nix ğ“†± Acht/Ast<brachio Branch,
yawÂ® â‹ yÄ ä¸« ä¸¨ä¸· yibÄ æ”¯ä¸« zhiYa zweiGe ææ¡  dual æœµ duÇ’ ears

â²® â²¯ 700 Epsi Î¨, Ïˆ psi vs Ypsilon ğ°± IC *YPC Ypsilon psi ÑŒ ybsilent

Prime examples are the modern letters ×¢ 'Ayin and ypsilon for which it is known that they had some consonant component which was historically lost some centuries ago.

While it's easy to assume that some (if not all) readings of the Egyptian syllables have been run down by the millenia, it's harder to nail down which exactly, and what the original forms might have been. Let's start by going half the way, by looking at modern readings of Greek and Aramaic and their likely original forms.

We hereby postulate, that
Îµ < Î£
Ï… < Î³ > y
â²¨ < r or
â²¨ < Î³ or both: 'gyar'
Ï¥ < hetha Ä§ áµ—h ×— ášºáš»
á½„ < ×¡ solar > helio > el
Î· < hn â‹ Î· = 'É™'
á¼¡ might be proper h: hemi<semi<Î´emi>demi (half) á¼¡ might be very soft t/d/c < Î´ related to ×” = *áµ—h Î³ even today is gjâ‹y/dj/sh

corroboration:

The Berber signs â´¸=Î” V=âµ  gv/dv dual â´µ
The Berber sign âµ‰ = y (Î£ silent)

It is pretty obvious if you look at the form of the characters Îµâ‹Î£ and the greek vocabulary:

á¼‘Ï€Ï„Î¬ = sá¼‘pta (seven)
á¼‘Ï„ÎµÏÏŒ = cetera > heteros > others
á¼‘ÏÏ€ÎµÏ„ÏŒÎ½ = serpent â‹ Ï§â²â²“â²£â²“

á¼‘Î²Î´Î¿Î¼Î®ÎºÎ¿Î½Ï„Î± = seve'-time-counte = seventy (70)
á¼™Î²ÏÎ±ÏŠ â‹ Zebra Õ¦Õ¥Õ¢Ö€ à¦œà§‡à¦¬à¦°à¦¾ Ø²ÙŠØ¨Ø±Ùˆ > Cyprid > Hybrid > Hebrew â‡”
á½‘Ï€Î­Ï *Ã¼per super/duper/guper > hyper > Ã¼ber > over

The only question is when did those signs become silent, in which dialect?

Greek already possessing other g and s sound poses no problem:
1. There might have been different variants of s, just like today we have Câ‹sâ‹shâ‹ÃŸâ‹Å›â‹Åâ‹Å¡â‹È™â‹ÅŸ
2. Likewise we write 'g' for game and giraffe, both different sounds
3. At the time of Homeric writing some dialects might have already swallowed the sounds

The main difficulty of this theory is that assigning a new value to Îµ would in consequence result in words, which are unfamiliar to us today, despite the clear connections:
á¼‘Ï„ÎµÏÏŒ = cetera ok with the diacritic mark á¼‘â‰ Îµ, but
ÎµÏ„ÎµÏÏŒ in earlier times might consequently have been cetcero (â‡”ÎºÎ±Î¸Î±ÏÏŒÏ‚?)
á¼‘ÏÏ€ÎµÏ„ÏŒÎ½ = serpáº½ton > serpent python with diacritics or
á¼‘ÏÏ€ÎµÏ„ÏŒÎ½ = serpeston > serpent pest <?> Karpusteln

The true pronounciation will forever be unknowable, anyone 'proving' how to correctly pronounce even 1000 year old words is a fool, however we can outline plausible arguments of continuation and similarity, hopefully yielding in somewhat close approximations, but all too likely way off.

The same y <â‹ j <â‹ gj <â‹ 'silent s' shift seems to have occured further east of Greek:

Keep in mind that there are and where many sounds/phonemes which are foreign to our ears, and hard for us to produce. https://hooktube.com/watch?v=-zB2TG9sVf8
